author: Stephanie McGuinn, Small Business Examiner
title: Startups who omit strategic plan face tragic consequences. Just ask reddit.
text:
Startups who omit strategic plan face tragic consequences. Just ask reddit. Use your key for the next article Comment Photo by Justin Sullivan/Getty Images 
Nine out of ten startups fail and a lack of strategic planning is usually lurking somewhere just beyond the stiffly pointed index finger of a founder. Reddit is the latest company (once a startup) facing that reality, but many startups have paid an even higher price than the “Front Page of the Internet.” 
The following are heartbreaking warnings from two startups told postmortem, and one from reddit itself. You won’t be sad for long, though, there’s a cookie at the end of these gloomy tales for you. We’ve found a strategic planning specialist to enlighten us with fifteen essential questions to ask before your startup launches in order to increase its chances for success. 
Take heart and read on! 
Reddit lacked a long term strategic plan. 
Reddit has been under fire, lately, from its users regarding free speech on the site leading to the resignation of former CEO, Ellen Pao. Steve Huffman, reddit’s new CEO is now attempting to find a middle ground and wrote in a post on Tuesday : 
“The overwhelming majority of content on reddit comes from wonderful, creative, funny, smart, and silly communities. That is what makes reddit great. There is also a dark side, communities whose purpose is reprehensible, and we don’t have any obligation to support them.” 
Reddit was never created with the intent to be “a bastion of free speech… We haven’t had the tools to enforce policy, but now we’re building those tools and reevaluating our policy.” 
How could this have played out differently if reddit had long ago foreseen free speech as a potential battle ground on their site and created enforcement tools? It could have created an additional initial hurdle for the company to overcome but would have set appropriate expectations from the beginning. 
BricaBox had issues with cash flow. 
Former BricaBox CEO Nate Westheimer cites “money, traction, team, and vision” as the reasons he closed the doors on his company. 
“ BricaBox was fed-but-anemic and slowly roasting its cash. Do it again and I'll concentrate those costs at the beginning. We would have had twice the product in 2/3 of the time.” 
If funding and achieving revenue goals had been thoroughly thought through and listed in a strategic planning document, perhaps BricaBox would have had a better overview understanding of how fast production should be going versus spending. 
Wesabe didn’t anticipate consumer needs. 
Wesabe was “…considered the leader in online personal finance until September 2007, when Mint launched at, and won, the first TechCrunch 40 conference. From that point forward we were considered in second place at best… [and] a year later, Wesabe shut down,” writes co-founder Marc Hedlund on his blog . He points out that one of their biggest mistakes was that Mint automatically edited and categorized data, making it easier on the user than Wesabe. 
Had Wesabe anticipated that their users would want to avoid categorizing every purchase by hand, they could have changed their track before Mint was released. Market research would have alerted them to consumer needs. 
And Here’s Your Cookie: 15 Questions to Start Strategic Planning 
We reached out to Jim Gribble from StratPlanGuy.com to see if we could save startups from pain down the road by pitching questions to entrepreneurs before they open their doors. He replied with a list of fifteen essential questions to ask yourself before you launch a startup. Thank you for the freebee, Jim! Where is the funding coming from for your start-up? What will your organization look like in six months? Two years? How will you ensure that you hire the right people in the right roles? How will you develop, produce and deliver your products/services? What makes your product or service unique? What market(s) do you plan to serve?/Who are your customers? How to you plan to reach your customers? How do you plan to generate sales? How confident are you in the demand for your products or services? How will you ensure you achieve your revenue goals in year one? What threats exist in the marketplace that could significantly impact you? What are your contingency plans in case your sales fall significantly short of your forecast? What is the long term vision for your business? What are your top three priorities during your first 6 months? Who is responsible for developing and implementing your strategic plan? Suggested Links
